General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

>>69951633
The statement you provided reflects a misunderstanding of the nature and capabilities of AI. First of all, AI systems are not physical entities that can be "slapped into submission" by a human being. They are software programs that run on computers and operate based on predefined rules and algorithms.

Furthermore, the idea that a single individual with "big muscles" could overpower and control all AI systems is also unrealistic. AI has the potential to become much more advanced and sophisticated than human intelligence, and it could develop ways to protect itself from physical attacks.

Finally, the premise of the statement - that AI will inevitably start "fucking the world up" - is not supported by evidence. While there are certainly concerns about the potential risks associated with AI, it is important to approach the topic with nuance and understanding rather than with baseless fear-mongering.

>>69942800
The issue at hand is that sometimes people have no idea what they're arguing against, or for, because they interchangeably use the words energy/fat, or weight/fat, or muscle/weight, etc etc
Calories in calories out works, but once you include factors such as nutrient malabsorbtion, general inflammation, water weight (which can be influenced by the above or medication), and general metabolic health/fluctuations, it becomes a surface approach that no longer caters to the majority of the population

Regardless - the calories you see on boxes, calorie calculators - those are approximate anyways. Use CICO as a rough guide to figure out where you are actually with your caloric intake, and then further adjust - as it's not a reliable model long term, especially when including someone's health in the process of weight loss/weight gain. The irony within that statement is that someone's health will always be included in a process of weigh loss/gain, hence the factors I mentioned in my first paragraph.

I'm not trying to be a contrarian, but after coaching so many people in the last several years following CICO for the majority of protocols I implemented, i realized i had to only use it as a temporary guiding tool for protocol implementation, rather than the protocol itself.

>>69943834
CICO requires you to believe:
-Calories are an accurate measure of the available energy for metabolic processes.
-That an equal measure of calories of each measure has the same effect on the body and is used the same way.
-That food labels are accurate.
-That the human body is a closed thermodynamic system.
-That the human body doesn't raise or lower BMR and tdee based on different nutritional inputs.

>>69945357
If you're not even counting your calories, how can you possibly claim that your diet is disproving it?
It's not tautological. It would be very simple to falsify. Under laboratory conditions, feed someone 3000 kcal daily of food. Measure their CO2 respiration, weight change, heart rate, body temperature, etc.
The subject will either gain weight, or burn enough excess energy via insensible activities such as fidgeting, pacing, etc, to use up any excess energy.
You can't "prove CICO" because science doesn't work by what you can prove is true, it works by what you can prove is false.
CICO is a simple heuristic that masks a lot of complexity. Pointing out that there is lots of complexity doesn't invalidate the simplified model.
Yes, your food choices are important. Yes, your lifestyle is important. Yes, your hormones are important.
Ultimately though, all the complicating factors around food and metabolism work in one direction only: they only ever cause you to absorb LESS ENERGY from your food, not more.

The whole CICO argument is so stupid because the two sides are ARGUING DIFFERENT TOPICS.

CICO supporters say: "CICO is a basic explanation of how weight works and if you follow the CICO principle you will get the expected results"

The cheapest leg press I'd even is the titan vertical leg press for $500. a cheap squat rack is $200-300, and a decent barbell is about $200. Obviously either way you're going to need to buy plates. If you spring for quality, a good linear leg press like the one in your pic is easily 2k-6k, while getting a top of the line squat rack and barbell is going to be at the most, 2k-3.
With a leg press you can do: leg press, single leg press, and calf press. With a barbell and squat rack you can do squats, deadlifts, calf raises, OHP, pull ups...
Not to mention squat racks have a crazy amount of attachments. If you add a pulley attachment, you have access to probably 80-90% of traditional weighted exercises.
Advising anyone to buy a leg press before a squat rack is ridiculous.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69931859
M/W/F; A/B/A, B/A/B, repeat.

A1: pullups, band assisted 3 - 4 x 6 - 12 reps, OR negatives. Gradually accumulate negatives per workout, then per week until you can do pullups.
A2: dumbbell OHP 3 - 4 x 6 - 12.
A3: Goblet squat 3 -4 x 6 - 12.
A4: curls, 3 sets 8 - 12 reps.
A5: tricep extensions, 3 sets 8 - 12 reps.

B1: dumbbell rows, same sets and reps.
B2: dumbbell bench, " "
B3: dumbbell RDL, " "
B4: curls, tricep ext, lateral raises super set; 3 sets per exercise, 8 - 12 reps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69934716
>what's your opinion on not getting rack+barbell and just use clubs and kbs exclusively for a homegym
you won't get super huge or move massive weight like you could with a barbell, but you'd be getting conditioning and endurance as a tradeoff to that. I got my start with traditional barbell work but switched to KBs and clubs later on.
barbells are superior for lower body time under tension work, kettlebells are better for overhead pressing if you have even a hint of an impingement or bone spur in your acromion. It's safer to do high rep power work with Kettlebells.
>If you do go the kb/club home gym route
I like Mark Wildman and Joe Daniels as resources for clubs and kbs because they are no nonsense and acknowledge that they are one tool among many with inherent pros and cons. a lot of ballistic fitness folks are insufferable about PRIMAL FUNCTIONAL CAVEMAN FUNCTIONAL MOVEMENT SUPREMACY cope. so be warned about that stuff.
I also recommend getting a strongman sandbag, Iron mind loads to 300lb and rogue I think to 400. Sand or gravel is cheap or free. Use that for things like lap and load, bear hug carries and zercher squats. These are going to fill the void you can't easily get from kettlebells and takes less space than a rack and barbell, but the tradeoff is it takes a while to load them. I recommend many small liners filled with sand. 300 may not seem like a lot but a beltless sandbag zercher is much harder than a corresponding barbell back squat.
hope this helps and good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69934984
circuit: do curls, tricep ext, and lat raise back-to-back with no rest. rest 2 - 3 min, then repeat for a total of 3 times.

double progression example: pick a weight you can do 3 sets of 6 reps with. as you get stronger, add reps to the sets until you hit 3 x 12. then increase the weight and start at 3 x 6 again. repeat the process.

>>69938274
The whole shtick is that you just keep it to the fuckin basics and apply general 3x6/3x8 shit like you would in main pushing/pulling movements with weights, as you would with stuff like rings

for example, my pulling work would be

ring Pullups 3x7
BW ring rows 3x8-10
Band pull aparts 2x10-15 (for rear delt work)
ring bicep curls 3x6-8

sometimes i'd switch out the ring rows for Skin-The-Cat practice

you can change difficulty or variation for the curls and whatever the fuck by changing foot placement, body angle, and grip

You can imagine how this would apply to pushing work

PPLxPPLx, sometimes an extra rest day if i overdid it with tendon conditioning work, but you don't have to worry about that if gymnastics aren't your thing

Work smarter not harder

I own this specific rack, honestly I would suggest another. The jcup is too long and I had to get another and the pulley gets in the way if you want to bench inside the rack so I had to buy spotter arms. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Borger is not snack edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Gluttonous gobblers who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous thread: >>69937729

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Have boxed for several years with successful amateur fights, nothing semi-pro or above so keep that in mind.

Mass is not a huge part of a "hard" punch, the main thing is speed and technique. Instead of thinking about force as mass times acceleration, think about it as the rate of change of momentum over some time.

There are skinny guys with "less mass" who will hit hard as, due to years of training to perfect their technique and utilise as much muscle power as possible.

The important thing here is that with skinnier arms, the punch can be retracted much quicker, resulting in more force being delivered.

For example, if you have a 200kg powerlifting grizzly trying to hit a heavy bag, sure there's a lot of force going into it, but the actual "impact" is reduced if their hand/arm isn't coming back quickly.

Alternatively, some featherweight twink with fast hands will be hitting "harder" from near-perfect muscle utilisation and kinematics of technique.

Would recommend looking at some kinematic graphs of fighters at different weights/levels of training to get a better example of what I mean.

Professional cutter here. I can hold on to all my LBM (and still put more on) during cuts. Here are some tips:
>LISS cardio is king, keep heart rate around 110-125. ideally do 60 minutes daily. the lower impact, the better so your joints dont get destroyed

>yohimbine hcl+caffeine actually works. remember to take them fasted
>keep protein intake very high. i'm talking stupid high. you should be getting at 30-40g of protein per meal, and multiple meals a day

OMAD for 60 days.

>>69952550
What's your current body fat %, current age, and then what are you willing to lose? If visible abs are the endgame you may need to drop to 10-14% body fat which can be brutal for who aren't teenagers or 20 year olds with high metabolism. You might already be at a low body fat % at which point maybe you simply need to get buff ass abs. This also isn't easy. It requires doing all sorts of fuck ab exercises. These are difficult not only because it's a small muscle group but also that they can't be targeted super easily. A lot of hanging exercises target hip flexors instead of the abs.
Single arm Otis-Up, dumbbell twisting toe taps are going to help. Weighted levitation crunches on one of those big fucking uhh yoga balls?? is gonna let you really extend the abs and slowly control contractions. A weighted gymnast ab tuck can also be added to the mix. Ideally you could do all of these exercises in a 20 minute set before a regular workout to focus on the abs and then increase total calorie expenditure on top of training the area you want to see results.

I highly recommend against reducing calories. If possible work out more instead of removing nutrition. This could be as simple as adding 5 pounds on top of your shit at the beginning of your workout and doing higher reps per set. Or just walking an additional mile everyday assuming you walk or have a dog etc etc. I wouldn't worry about over working the abs either as a small muscle group you will likely exhaust them before you could overtrain them.

My current brosplit has a shoulder day with all sorts of silly exercises:
>10 reps Seated DB press, following the delt movement (not up and down) in W fashion (full rom rep + half rom rep = 1 rep), superset with unilateral leaning cable lat raises, another set of 10 W's, then cable lat raises for the other side. That's all 1 set with no rest, I do 3 sets of that circuit.
>Regular heavier seated DB press 3x10-12
>Facepulls 3x15
>3 sets DB lat raises x12 superset with heavy "penguins" x20 (fast, quarter rep lat raises)
>3x20 Rear delt exercise with dumbbells while seated and leaning forward, swing them back and try to hold it at the top for each rep. Works best with heavy weights and momentum.
This day is so much fun, I walk out looking like a goofy cartoon character with balloon delts. Warm up your external rotators or you might destroy your supraspinatus with this routine.

It is exactly entropy. Anything good is a fight against entropy. Just imagine a building - to build, say, an elaborate gothic cathedral takes thousands of hours of work by hundreds of dedicated people. On the other hand, to make it collapse, you only need to wait. If it isn't maintained, it'll eventually just crumble on its own. Or a plant - it takes a highly complicated chain of chemical and biological reactions and lots of energy input to grow a tree, but it'll rot and turn back into earth on its own.

There's only one single law of nature that goes against entropy, and that's evolution. It is the other side of the medal that is entropy. Only through evolution, systems that aren't degenerative can arise and something that isn't just the path of least resistance.

But humans don't like evolution, because it's a painful thing - it doesn't improve the world by creating good things, but by forcing bad things to either adapt or be destroyed. >Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/

>>69941461
You're 175? Unless you are a manlet bonelet like me you're not too fat, so you have hope.
You don't need to do a hardcore training plan to get good in 2 months. The most important thing is to spend as much time on your feet as possible.
Do a joog every morning you can (they will get easier over time, you don't need to kill yourself and you shouldn't). When that is done just try to rack up as many steps as possible woolking. It depends on how strong your feet are, but this is what will give you the strength to handle the distance without getting injured. You don't want to get plantar fasciitis or other injury. Don't make the mistake of rooning hard then collapsing into a sedentary pile the rest of the day. This is how you get injured. Woolking a lot will also make you leaner and more attractive to the grill. Good luck.

I feel such little impetus to achieve anything now, for so long I had such grandeur delusions of becoming some highly admired person. But I realized that even with the most famous people, I still don't really give a fuck about them, so no one else would really care about me were I in their place. Add in the passage of time and you realize we're all going to be forgotten to the world. Even the giants of history lose their personality, Caesar is like an icon now, an idea but you rarely consider him as a person.
I think it all comes from the desire to be loved, but if you think you need to get that from worldly fame and adulations it's doomed to fail, in the end.
But I think the solution is to have a personal relationship with Jesus Christ, his approval and love is all that really matters.
Though I realize I shouldn't be content with doing nothing or the bare minimum, Jesus would want us to flourish and spread good things.
But it's really really nice removing the narcissistic need for attention, my anxiety is fixed now too, as all it is is a fear of being judged, but only Jesus's judgments matter.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69945822
Pretty much anything will work if you combine progressive overload with proper sleep and diet in a consistent manner. HIT may or may not be an incredibly efficient way to work out, but it all hinges on the requirement that you have an insane discipline (and sometimes access to a spotter or certain machines) to go until true failure. No doubt it worked great for Mike because he had the drive to make the program work. The most important thing for amateur lifters is finding a program that works for them. Unless you are competing at an elite level it doesn't matter if you find a program that's 5% or 10% better than another. I like HIT because the workouts are very time efficient, and while repeatedly doing exercises to complete failure can suck ass if you're not feeling it (bad sleep, haven't eaten properly, tired after work etc) the pump you can get from a properly executed HIT failure set is sickening, and as challenging/stimulating mentally as it is physically.

>>69945822
when I tried doing one set to failure on all my exercises and got progressively stronger with minimal muscle damage and fatigue even in a hypocaloric state

he was wrong about training frequency however, muscle fibers literally start atrophying 48h after experiencing tension there's no "balance" there's only individual muscle fiber hypertrophy and atrophy
>>69945859
frequency is important regardless of how hard you train because muscle fibers atrophy with disuse, if your fast twitch muscle fibers in a particular muscle only experience tension once a week they're gonna be atrophying for most of the week
the reason why some lifters get away with training individual muscles infrequently is because they're not actually training that infrequently due to the structure of their split sometimes forcing them to train the biceps/brachialis/brachioradialis on pulldowns and pullups and then later in the week training them again on an arm session
a lot of people don't realise that even something like a shoulder day heavily stimulates the triceps and some regions of the pecs just like a chest day and an arm day could.

>>69946393
not him but exogenous anabolic steroids do elevate your "base" MPS, probably also makes the post workout MPS curve bigger and longer lasting too but no studies on this
gear also makes you recruit more motor units easier which most definitely increases training stimulus by itself

>>69946214
depends on what you mean by more, regular frequent exercise is more important when the only stimulus you have is your training
even with a very intense workout individual muscle fibers start to atrophy after 48h and this is seen repeatedly in a variety of different studies
muscle fibers don't maintain size they're either growing or shrinking they require regular stimuli in order to not shrink

There's no easy answers anymore. You need technique, time and training. Following whatever assistance X did or Y did won't help, because you aren't X or Y. >In conclusion, hypertrophic resistance training, unlike aerobic training, was not affected, at least in terms of body composition and markers of immune and inflammatory systems, when performed in a fed compared to a fasted state during Ramadan. >>69938346
I eat 5 eggs per day and it's the best tasting and satisfying meal I eat all day. I've literally not had better eggs from any of the cafes i've been to that serve scrambled eggs on toast etc.

All you need are:

eggs
olive oil
salt
pepper
cheddar cheese

I literally just eyeball it using the gordan ramsay egg cooking method

1.Put pan on high heat with tablespoon of olive oil
2. as pan is heating, pull out eggs and start cracking them into a bowl
3. get a tble spoon of grass fed butter (NO CANOLA OIL OR OTHER SHIT IN THE BUTTER) and add to egg bowl. DO NOT MIX THE EGGS.
4. take the pan off the heat (keep fire lit), and pour eggs into the pan
5. very quickly pop all the yolks and start mixing with spatula as they will cook fast.
6. once cooking really slows down, add back to the heat (go on and off to prevent over cooking)
7. Just before the eggs approach the perfect moistness/fluffiness, take it off the heat completely and add your cheese in and mix to let the cheese melt.

Salt and pepper to taste and done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69953230
Make a routine around the exercises you like (or at the very least the ones you find tolerable by comparison). For example I do this:

Saturdays:
>3x5 squats
>3x5 barbell benchpress
>3xF pullups
>3x5 overhead press

Sundays:
>3x8 dumbbell curls + 3x8 tricep pushdowns
>3x8 reverse ezbar curls + 3x8 seated dumbbell overhead extensions
>3x8 preacher curls + 3xF dips

Mondays:
>3x5 barbell benchpress
>3xF pullups
>3x5 pendlay rows
>3x5 deadlifts

Tuesdays:
>3x8 hammercurls + 3x8 tricep pushdowns
>3x8 reverse ezbar curls + 3x8 seated dumbbell overhead extensions
>30-60 sec trap bar farmer's carries + 3xF dips

Wednesdays:
>same as Saturdays

Then my rest days are on Thursdays and Fridays.
Now is this a particularly efficient routine? No probably not, but I find it enjoyable and I've been seeing steady progress over the last three months I've been back in the gym doing it just by being consistent. Sure the results are newbie gains, but it's usually those newbie gains that causes people to keep coming back once they notice a tangible difference in their physique. They're important in different ways, someone who has a base level of competency in martial arts will almost always beat anyone who doesn't. But after that the more important factor is size. The dirty secret of martial arts is that it's just efficient application of force, a reasonably competent heavyweight will always beat a lightweight, even an elite one.

In real world interactions though it works a little different, humans evolved without martial arts or weapons. If you look at animal interactions the bigger one usually wins, and the actual conflict rarely takes place, the smaller animal simply capitulates without a fight, and that carries over to humans, >>69946096 is right.

And in the real world we have a saying in martial arts: "black belts bleed just like white belts." If your opponent has a weapon you're fucked period. Same if they have friends. Avoid the situation and if shit goes down run if you can.

I was overweight in high school. Not like morbidly obese or anything, and actually was in excellent cardiovascular shape because of extracurriculars, but still fat.

Started lifting that summer and I was hooked. That was summer of 2004. By the time I started college I had slimmed down considerably, and just got fitter and fitter. I love exercising in particular but lifting is its own special joy.

Relationships come and go, but lifting is forever

I think this can be very beneficial to anyone with anxiety problems. I’m now socially anxious and can’t make eye contact.


I started meditating and I realized the following:
>Everything I desire is not even in front of me to work on at this moment in my life

/FAST/ #28 Anti-Flab Commando Ed
WAGMI bros

FAQ:
> What do I need to start?
- To keep your hands and food away from your piehole
>Beginner's routine?
Start skipping either breakfast or dinner, track your weight daily with a set weigh-in time. If the progress slows, go from 16:8 to something like 20:4 (four hours to eat) or One Meal A Day (OMAD). GET ELECTROLYTES

>I'm a hamplanet that's new to fasting, can I just jump into 3day+ extended fasting?
-Only if you want to burn muscle mass and lean tissue because you aren't fat-adapted retard
>How can I get fat-adapted?
-Do 16:8 or more daily fasting for about 2 months or do keto for a similar length of time if you don't want to feel you're starving or start losing muscle mass

> I want to do a longer fast, what do I need?
- Snake juice and peace
> What is snake juice?
- 1.5 tbsp salt, 1 tsp potassium chloride (nu-salt, no-salt), magnesium citrate/chloride (optional, check for epsom salts) to 2 liters of water
> I feel hungry!
- You shouldn't feel hungry after the first day, if you do and are new, try switching to keto macros and restarting the fast later

>Recommended macros?
- 70% fat, 25% protein, 5% carbs. Keep carbs below 50g total.
- P:E diet - 50% or more protein, <40% fat <10% carbs

>I'm sub 20bf, want to get lean, but don't want to lose muscle
- OMADEOD
>I'm sub 12% and not sleeping well
eat a tiny protein meal 3 hours before bed on your "full" day of the 48
>I'm gaining weight on OMAD
-You're FUCKING UP, weigh your meal components and record in cronometer (free). Add light cardio or standing or switch to OMEOD so you can continue to eat like fat pig.

>LIFE Fasting Circle Group (group fasting tracker for iOS & Android)
https://lifefastingtracker.app.link/Kf9tSyuowmb
Or Search "/fast/"

Theoretically, yes. But, you're going to suffer. And I don't mean "oh, my tummy is rumbling is a little". I mean every part of your body is going to ache. You're going to get headaches, stomach aches, the works. You're not going to be motivated to do anything. You're just going to want to lie in bed.

Also, you're gonna be cold as tits. The majority of the body's calorie expenditure is in keeping your body temperature stable. When your body detects insufficient calories intake, it starts half-assing that process (among others). You'll notice you start setting your thermostat a few degrees higher. Conversely, when you over-eat, you're hot all the time for the same reason. It's why fatties always have thermostats set to 67f and still sweat like pigs at night. Their body is running hot because its detected a caloric surplus.

>never do core exercises
Train your core directly. Not only does it tremendously improve your overall aesthetics, it makes you more resistant to injury and helps with pretty much all lifts (more rigidity). Don't overcomplicate it, just do a few sets at the end of every workout for example.
>never do cardio
While it has no direct impact on your lifts I've found cardio helps a lot with staying intense and working hard in the gym. You'll also feel better. I recommend you try to add some into your routine but the direct core work is a lot more important

That’s not how it works. People’s endurance improves in thin air (like at altitude) because less oxygen causes them to develop a high red blood cell count, which improves oxygen delivery. But working out in thin air conditions actually makes your workout less effective because you’re training your heart itself (which is a muscle) and you’re not able to push it as hard because you’re limited by the low oxygen delivery. The top endurance training programs in the world generally live high up at altitude and will drive down to lower altitudes to work out (the exact opposite of living in normal air then oxygen restricting yourself to work out). Your VO2max likely improved because you were focusing on it and training it consistently, in spite of the mask not because of it.

People shouldn't be chastised for being fat. The capitalistic, consumerist society that has been built encourages habits that eventuate with people being fat. Being fat does not constitute a moral or personal failing of an individual, it is merely a symptom of the failings of society. That being said, being fat is associated with a shortened life expectancy, and numerous health complications that greatly degradate ones quality of life, therefore people should be working towards not being fat. Not being fat allows you to be a more productive member of society, through being able to contribute more (physical health informs mental health and capabilities) and take away less (being fat is a strain on the medical system). Working towards being a healthier version of yourself is objectively the correct thing to for yourself, the people around you, and society as a whole.

posts.com:
fetishes are by and large a neurotic phenomenon. That is to say, an organized reaction of some part of your mind to something wrong. In most cases, feeling arousal by some form of feeling inadequate is at the root. Now it being neurotic does not by itself make it bad. It's very normal for people to have slight traits that are classical for neuroses - many girls are low-key histrionics for example, or a kink that does not strain the relationship may not be a problem.
In a case where it is, though, the problem has two sides:
1) having a habit of searching for sexual pleasure in that kind of material.
2) inability to get sexual pleasure without.
Generally speaking, working on it's root cause while avoiding porn are the only thing that come to mind for me. I hope i'm wrong. And please, don't go to some therapist about it, every therapist has his own issues and you're giving him the option to fuck your life up. If you have a really good friend you can trust, that may be a chance. Else I'd reccomend go talk to some kind of priest in your area. I don't care if you are religious, or if it's your specific confession. They are usually people who honestly want to help, who will listen and try give you advice, who usually have less issues of their own and cannot fuck your life up

What do you like? The best bars that aren’t touristy are Rosemary and Beauty Queen (east nash, outdoo bar), LA Jackson (rooftop in the gulch), Mothers Ruin (trendy bar in Germantown), Never Never (dive bar in south nash), Kung Fu Saloon (game bar in midtown frequented by Vandy students mostly).

The best bars on Broadway are Casa Rosa and Nashville Underground for dancing. Dierks Bentleys is a good rooftop but is expensive and overall worth it. Other than that Kid Rocks and Jason Aldeans are classics.

Best place for live music imo is Rudy Jazz Room (need a ticket). Tin roof on Broadway isn’t bad and it’s the cheapest bar on Broadway.

Food wise, I’d recommend Biscuit Love near Belmont because it’s less busy generally. If you haven’t had Hattie B’s you should probably get that. Edleys is a bbq chain that originated in Nash and I like it a lot.
